text: The steeds of the Midnight Aristocracy are unnatural destriers called Nightmares. They are Undead stallions clad in baroque barding.
The steeds of the Midnight Aristocracy are unnatural destriers called Nightmares. They are Undead stallions clad in baroque barding.
Harkon's personal mount is a dreadful thing indeed - a Terrorgheist with a piercing, banshee-like shriek that has the power to stun any who hear it.
Long-dead destriers, awakened to serve their Unliving masters far beyond death.
The pride of Nehekharan armies, impacting enemy lines with bone-shattering force and grinding the corpses beneath their heavy wheels.

The dread abyssal ridden by Mannfred von Carstein was known to myth as Ashigaroth. Now reborn as a creature of chill bone in the mortal world, Ashigaroth hunts the living as readily as it ever did the dead, galloping through the skies to follow the spirit-spoor of prey.

The dread abyssal ridden by Arkhan the Black was known to myth as Razarak. Whilst other dread abyssals scoured the depths of the Underworld, Razarak always sought lofty perches from which to track its prey. Such behavior was well-suited to its duties, for treachery is best judged from on high.

The dread abyssal ridden by Neferata was known to myth as Nagadron. So voracious is Nagadron that it needs little goading to feast upon other prey, and gorges itself upon the living as eagerly as it did the souls of the dead.

Nagash's armour is forged from an alloy of lead and meteoric iron. Over the millennia the armour has fused itself with his body, so it may only be worn by Nagash. Obviously, the armour does not prevent him casting spells.

Mortis is a huge magic sword that crackles with unearthly power. The blade was forged and enchanted by Nagash himself and no-one else may use it. The sword increases his already considerable strength, and wounds caused by the sword can be used to heal Nagash himself.
The Staff of Power was created by Nagash to allow him to store the additional power he needed to carry out his most arcane and dangerous magical spells.

The Crown of Nagash sometimes known as the Crown of Sorcery is a magical crown/circlet forged by the great Necromancer Nagash around -1300 IC in his fortress of Nagashizzar in Cripple Peak. The crown is infused with part of Nagash's malicious spirit, partially holding his spirit to the mortal world, and exerts a corrupting influence on anyone who wears it.

The Crown of Nagash sometimes known as the Crown of Sorcery is a magical crown/circlet forged by the great Necromancer Nagash around -1300 IC in his fortress of Nagashizzar in Cripple Peak. The crown is infused with part of Nagash's malicious spirit, partially holding his spirit to the mortal world, and exerts a corrupting influence on anyone who wears it.
The first book of Nagash's greatest spell tomes known as the Nine Books of Nagash.
The second book of Nagash's greatest spell tomes known as the Nine Books of Nagash.
The third book of Nagash's greatest spell tomes known as the Nine Books of Nagash.
The fourth book of Nagash's greatest spell tomes known as the Nine Books of Nagash.
The fifth book of Nagash's greatest spell tomes known as the Nine Books of Nagash.
The sixth book of Nagash's greatest spell tomes known as the Nine Books of Nagash.
The seventh book of Nagash's greatest spell tomes known as the Nine Books of Nagash.
The eighth book of Nagash's greatest spell tomes known as the Nine Books of Nagash.
The ninth and final book of Nagash's greatest spell tomes known as the Nine Books of Nagash.
The second book of Nagash's greatest spell tomes known as the Nine Books of Nagash.
The third book of Nagash's greatest spell tomes known as the Nine Books of Nagash.
The eighth book of Nagash's greatest spell tomes known as the Nine Books of Nagash.
A product of twisted sorcery, this construct fuses with the wearer, giving him tremendous endurance.
Whenever this blade tastes blood, its wielder seems to exert greater control over the Winds of Magic.
The sword burns away the flesh of Arkhan's victims, leaving nothing but a charred skeleton, bound to the Liche King's dark will for all eternity.
Created by the Arch-Necromancer, the staff harnesses Dark Magic from deep within the accursed Black Pyramid.
It is well known that Lustrian gold is enchanted with all manner of esoteric properties; Harkon thinks it will restore his fractured mind!
The blades cursed edge screams with the death agonies of innocents and saps the vitality and fighting spirit of its victims.
It's wicked enchantments add crippling agonies to any sorceries she wields.
It's wicked enchantments add crippling agonies to any sorceries she wields.
An ancestral ring, set with a gem of deep, sanguine claret that has granted the von Carsteins everlasting Undeath.
This accursed blade drinks deep of its victim's blood, restoring vigour and strength to the one who brandishes it.
The life essence of many wretched, innocent smallfolk ensures that those who drink from this cursed cup thrive with newfound power.
Hellsteeds are the unholy fusion of horse and giant bat, bound by Dark Magic - a fitting steed for a Vampire noble.
The steeds of the Midnight Aristocracy are unnatural destriers called Nightmares - Undead stallions clad in baroque barding.
This cursed blade fills its wielder with an unholy energy, but also entraps the souls of those it cleaves including its former master, binding their jleshless remains in servitude.

The passage of the ages has strengthened rather than weakened this elaborate Chaos plate armour. Such is the aura of entropy that surrounds it that it has the power to decay the magic of enemy weapons in an instant.
When the Black Axe of Krell bites into flesh, it leaves behind jagged shards that swiftly eat their way into the victim's heart.
Long-dead destriers, awakened to serve their Unliving masters far beyond death.
The pride of Nehekharan armies, impacting enemy lines with bone-shattering force and grinding the corpses beneath their heavy wheels.
Long-dead destriers, awakened to serve their Unliving masters far beyond death.
The pride of Nehekharan armies, impacting enemy lines with bone-shattering force and grinding the corpses beneath their heavy wheels.
Giant leonine statues, almost impervious to harm; they wade through foes, crushing them like bothersome insects.
Long-dead destriers, awakened to serve their Unliving masters far beyond death.
Long-dead destriers, awakened to serve their Unliving masters far beyond death.
Long-dead destriers, awakened to serve their Unliving masters far beyond death.
Long-dead destriers, awakened to serve their Unliving masters far beyond death.
Long-dead destriers, awakened to serve their Unliving masters far beyond death.
The steeds of the Midnight Aristocracy are unnatural destriers called Nightmares. They are Undead stallions clad in baroque barding.
Hellsteeds are the unholy fusion of horse and giant bat, bound by Dark Magic - a fitting steed for a Vampire noble.
The steeds of the Midnight Aristocracy are unnatural destriers called Nightmares. They are Undead stallions clad in baroque barding.
Hellsteeds are the unholy fusion of horse and giant bat, bound by Dark Magic - a fitting steed for a Vampire noble.
A Wight King was once a Chieftain or a warrior-king of his tribe and so may have been buried with a loyal steed that still wears its rusted barding.
The Wight King calls forth a spectral steed of bone to ride upon, should he have favoured it during his once-lived life.
The unnatural speed and brutality of a reanimated Promethean makes it the ideal mount for any Undead, battle-mongering pirate.
The steeds of the Midnight Aristocracy are unnatural destriers called Nightmares. They are Undead stallions clad in baroque barding.
Hellsteeds are the unholy fusion of horse and giant bat, bound by Dark Magic - a fitting steed for a Vampire noble.
Animated by Dark Magic, a zombie dragon is an unholy parody of a once-noble beast now borne aloft by great tattered wings, its body covered with thick, withered hide.
Corpse Carts act like magnets for Dark Magic, drawing their power from the land itself and re-animating the dead around them.
Its brazier burning with supernatural flames, the Cart spits Warpstone – and the madness therein – upon enemy Wizards in its path.
Some Corpse Carts have a great bell mounted upon them, its ominous knell drawing the dead back to shambling Unlife.
A powerful Necromancer may be deemed worthy to ride on once-proud steeds, now risen to become Nightmares clad in dread barding.
Should the Necromancers please their Vampire masters they may well be gifted with Hellsteeds - winged Nightmares.
No ordinary armour would suit a Warboss such as Azhag, it had to be ‘ard - really, really ‘ard.

The Crown of Sorcery was found in the ruins of Todtheim by Azhag the Slaughterer. Its malign influence has helped the Warboss carve a path of destruction throughout the Empire, for the Crown whispers advice and grants the wearer the power of Death Magic.
The crude twin blades wielded by Azhag the Slaughterer are known as Slagga’s Slashas, but just who is Slagga?

An enemy so hated by the Hand that he was strapped on a halberd and is used as a battlestandard even after death. Those who came close enough and survived swear that the skeleton still screams in agony. Without a sound, yet unbearably loud.
A gift from Nagash himself. When its wielder fades, the blade awakens and feeds him with the life force of its victims so he may persist against all odds.
Claiming the souls of the living, trapped inside the sword. once filled allows the summoning of great warriors
The simple clay vessel may not look like much, but the High Priest's Undying essence within can thwart sorcery and strengthen incantations.
These eight magical scrolls, containing the sum total of Neferra's lifetime of learning, can whip up an unstoppable hurricane of power to crush the foe.
Forged from bronze, cooled in the blood of the giant Lybrasian scorpion, and gilded in red and Lahmian gold, this ancient breastplate will turn aside all but the strongest of blows.
These ornate armour plates are decorated with the likeness of the Scorpion-God; his protective energies pervade the very metal used, offering additional protection to the wearer.
The elaborate piece of jewellery hampers the effectiveness of Dark Magic ranged against it.
The desert itself shall be your coat... and the foe's undoing.
One sip of the elixir fills the body of its drinker with the strength of many powerful, elite warriors.
Death's foul taint hangs heavy from Prince Kharnut's elaborate deathmask, gripping the hearts of those who gaze upon it and freezing them in terror.
Sealed and bound with powerful glyphs, this jar contains the remains of a Liche Priest and all the magical energy at his command.
Infused with the sun's dazzling intensity, the power harnessed within gleams brilliantly, blinding the wearer's opponents.
This banner is wrought with powerful incantations that draw the ancient dead to it and bind their souls to the remains of long-dead warriors.
Containing the spirits of King Lahmizzar's Jackal Legion, this banner restores the fallen so they might fulfil their undying pledge.
This moon-shaped amulet projects a disruptive magical energy onto the enemy's defences.
This Tomb Prince's magical sword draws lifeforce from the slain to imbue the body of its wielder with stolen essence.
Forged in the heart of Settra's pyramid, only sorrow and despair are left behind when this enchanted blade has done its deadly work.
The very late King Setep's ornamented, curved sword shimmers with a blue hue that shatters the foe's armour.
All in the presence of these weapons' bearer are strangely humbled by the aura of majesty they convey.
This enchanted, impossibly-sharp blade can cleave through armour, flesh, bone and souls with equal ease, reducing victims to a lifeless husk.
Fashioned from interlocking tentacles and seashells and permanently dripping with slime, this armour clings to the wearer's body, allowing them to move freely.
Every pirate's favourite, this buckler is layered with Sea-Dragon scales which provide reliable protection yet weigh virtually nothing.
A long-lost treasure map, leading to long-lost treasure. Due to its accuracy and level of detail, it can also double as a battle map.
The classic pirate brew. It makes one extremely fiery... in every way!
These incendiary chemicals give ordinary shot that special glow as it flies towards the target, turning them into a screaming, staggering torch on contact.
The former owners of this banner have no further use for it themselves…
War Standard o' the Corpse Surgeons
You'd think there'd be no need for surgery on a ship crewed by the dead, but you'd be wrong - someone who can sew limbs back on double-quick is worth their weight in grog!
The owner of this chest refuses to let go of it even though they're dead.
Never give the zombies explosives, they'll blow the whole ship apart - you, me, the loot... everything!
In these days of grand alliances and complex treaties, there is something to be said for making your intentions abundantly clear from the outset.
Practice makes perfect, in Dark Magic as in all things.
These lost souls follow only the tides and currents now.

Crafted from the highest-quality blackpearl, legends state that its wearer will be granted the ability to see through the black ocean waters all the way to the sea floor, where untold fortunes are buried.
It won't kill yer - again - but the pain will make you wish it had.
A small dagger made from the tusk of a ferocious sea monster, as cold as the ocean is deep.
From years of sword fighting, or maybe just a moment's rum luck when a pistol backfired, real hands are nevertheless in short supply among pirates.
This eastern pirate blade, unmatched in its lethal sharpness, imbues its new owner with a portion of its previous wielder's power and skill.
Discovered in a vault deep inside Castle Drachenfels, the aura of gloom that clings to the Nightshroud is so strong it physically manifests as armour.
Woven from the wind and the cold, the chill of this banner touches the hearts of those who stand before it, sapping their will and ability to fight.
These magnificent hats are a visual proclamation of eternal dominion, reminding all who behold them of the indomitable force their wearers have become.
It wanders amidst the war-torn battlefield, its eyes fixed on those desperately clinging to the fading embers of life. Its purpose, is to liberate them from the torment of existence.
Entrusted with the solemn duty of preserving and safeguarding ancient tomes of forbidden knowledge and arcane secrets.
Warpstone is Dark Magic incarnate. Undead Lords, especially liches, will employ ghoulish hunters to find such precious ore.
Warlocks are those that practise the dark arts away from prying eyes. Their novice skill often make them the prey of Witch Hunters and more...
Corpses my master, how many do you need? Yes.
Even the steeds of the damned need a stable-hand to keep them fit and healthy... It's a difficult task trying to saddle a phantom horse though.
Won a battle with 4 or more cavalry units
Carrion are large, Undead, vulture-like creatures that are drawn to battlefields and Unholy summonings.
Ranked-up in a province with low corruption
Great Necromancer, I beseech you, my master, to look upon me with favor and grant me the power to serve you.
Ghouls, wretched little creatures, nothing more than prowlers of the dead.
Idle in a region with a Fields building
The ethereal voice of the siren calms the dead souls, allowing the Necromancer to bind them more easily.
Those spirits who are no longer bound to the mortal plane, can be tethered to his service - for poltergeists have their uses...
All this one needs is a dark damp cell, a morbid curiosity and plenty of samples to work with.
Spells of decay, curses of suffering, and necrotic incantations flow effortlessly from its bone-chilling voice, resonating with an unholy resonance that can freeze even the bravest of hearts.
Ranked-up in a province with high corruption
Beware the allure of beauty that dazzles the eye, for it can mask a treacherous heart. Gilded masks and refined manners hide the true nature of those who walk these unhallowed halls.
Carried out a successful [[img:icon_hero]][[/img]]Hero action against a character
Skilled hands, weathered by time, expertly wield embalming tools, delicately preparing the deceased for their eternal journey.
A blood bag to sustain the insatiable hunger of an immortal creature, that feeds upon the essence of life itself.
Won a battle against a human army
It's an extremely dirty and dangerous job, but someone has to do it. After all, even the highest-rated admiral had to start somewhere.
O heart! heart! heart! O the bleeding drops of red, where on the deck my Captain stands, cold and undead.
These ancient architects have designed the most opulent, elaborate crypts and vaults. Too skilled to be allowed to rest.
An imposing monument to Nehekhara's former power, now living once again in service of its new Master.
Win a battle against a Tomb King army
As the Undead rip apart their victims they feast on the organs that spill forth – regaining strength in the process.
Dance, dance and hear the sweet sound of death, loss, and the macabre, mourn as we delve into the depths of despair.
Ranked-up after winning 6 or more offensive battles
Cross their path and test fate as misfortune befalls you, these black cats are said to be the familiars of warlocks and witches, or perhaps they are just cats afterall.
You're the best! Can I... Can I follow you around? I won't get in the way! Can I carry your weapon? Shine your boots? Backrub, perhaps?

Azhag’s pet wyvern is called Skullmuncha - a gift from the Night Goblins of Red Eye Mountain. The wyvern was fierce, but Azhag immediately calmed the beast with one of his “best glares”; the two have been inseparable ever since.
Hellsteeds are the unholy fusion of horse and giant bat, bound by Dark Magic - a fitting steed for a Vampire noble.
The Black Jewel of the Dread King contains his very soul. Embedded in his rib cage, it beats like an obscene, black and glistening heart.
